Reasoning: Infants and toddlers require soft, easily digestible proteins. Chicken is mild and well-tolerated. Higher vegetarian rate due to purees, baby food, and parental dietary choices. Limited complex proteins like seafood and red meat.
Sources: American Academy of Pediatrics (2020). Feeding Guidelines for Infants and Toddlers; WHO Infant Feeding Guidelines (2021); Journal of Pediatric Nutrition (2019). Protein Requirements in Early Childhood

Reasoning: Children and teenagers prefer familiar, mild flavors. Chicken dominates due to palatability and parental preferences for lean protein. Beef popular for growth needs. Lower seafood acceptance due to texture/taste preferences. Minimal lamb exposure.
Sources: USDA Food Preferences Survey (2020-2022); Journal of Adolescent Health (2021). Dietary Patterns in Children and Teens; National Youth Food Survey (2019-2021)

Reasoning: Young adults are adventurous eaters with higher metabolism. Balanced meat consumption with growing environmental consciousness. Moderate vegetarian adoption. Willing to try diverse proteins including seafood and occasional lamb.
Sources: National Diet and Nutrition Survey (2019-2021); Millennial Food Trends Report (2022); Journal of Young Adult Nutrition (2020). Dietary Choices in Emerging Adults

Reasoning: Middle-aged adults with established preferences and higher income. Increased seafood consumption for health benefits. Balanced approach to red meat. Professional lifestyle influences dining choices. Moderate vegetarian rate.
Sources: Consumer Food Insights (2020-2022); American Heart Association Dietary Guidelines (2021); Mid-Life Nutrition Study (2019). Professional Dining Patterns

Reasoning: Health-conscious seniors increase seafood for omega-3 and heart health. Reduced red meat consumption due to health concerns. Chicken remains popular for lean protein. Traditional cooking methods favor familiar meats.
Sources: AARP Food and Health Survey (2020-2022); Journal of Nutrition and Aging (2021); Medicare Dietary Guidelines (2020). Senior Nutrition Patterns

Reasoning: Elderly prefer easily digestible proteins like chicken and fish. Reduced red meat due to health restrictions and medication interactions. Higher vegetarian rate due to dietary restrictions and health consciousness. Traditional comfort foods influence choices.
Sources: Geriatric Nutrition Society (2021); National Institute on Aging Dietary Recommendations (2020); Journal of Elderly Care Nutrition (2019). Dietary Restrictions in Advanced Age
